The Chief of Naval Staff reminded the War Cabinet that,at their last meeting on the 17th November, 1939, the Supreme WarCouncil had agreed that the Military experts in France and GreatBritain should study plans for operations in South East Europe.The French Ambassador had recently proposed to the permanent under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs that there should be ameeting in Paris the following week of the Comity d'Etudes, i.e.,the Permanent Military Representatives. The/French had, more-over, suggested that this body should not necessarily include theFrench Permanent Military Representatives now in London. it seemed possible that General Gamelin himself would wish to take part in any discussions in Paris. General Weygand was shortlyreturning to Paris, and would probably be associated with any such conversations. He was believed to have rather far-reaching ideasfor Staff Conversations with the various Balkan countries, and theChiefs of Staff were therefore somewhat apprehensive of the'proposal for a meeting in Paris.The Joint Planning Committee had drafted anew Appreciationcovering oUr strategy in the Balkans and the Middle East, whichwould be considered by the Chiefs of Staff oh/Thursday, the 30thNovember. The Chiefs of Staff would prefer not to initiate anyAnglo-French discussions until they-had had time to examine this new Appreciation. They therefore favoured a reply to the Frenchsuggesting, first, that the French Military Representatives inLondon/should be furnished forthwitht with; the views, in general terms, held by the French High Command oh; this subject; and,secondly, that the discussions should be /stajrtod at an early date,-v^^fi the mac in the form ofthe Permanent Military' Representatives;- i'' /,Tihe Secretary of-State, for Wotei:g&,A$idrs agreed that itwould be preferable to defer any discussions ^rothithe French un'**the Chiefs of Staff had approved the in draft, He also agreed that our reply might indicate a preference for dealing with the matter by the existing machinery. At the same time it was important not to adopt too rigid an attitude on a question of procedure. Our reply might include, therefore, a statement to the effect that, if General Gamelin himself wished to take part in the discussions, we should be ready to meet his convenience and send officers of appropriate status to Paris. We could not very well press General Gamelin himself to come to London again so soon after his last visit.
The War Cabinet agreed:-
That the terms of the reply to the suggestion of the French Ambassador should be framed in accordance with the discussion recorded above; and should include the following points:-
(i) An invitation to the French to communicate forthwith the views held by the French High Command on this subject.
(ii) A preference for dealing with this matter through the machinery of the Permanent Military Representatives in London.
(iii) A willingness to meet General Gamelin's convenience by holding a meeting in Paris of Officers of suitable rank, if he desired to take part in the discussions.
Roumania. Conversion of Danube grain barges for transport of oil to Germany (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 98rd Conclusions, Minute 12.)
6. The Minister without Portfolio reported that it had now been definitely ascertained that the Germans were installing tanks in Danube grain barges for carrying oil.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
7. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs drew the attention of the War Cabinet to Vatican telegram No. 97, which contained interesting information regarding Signor Mussolini's increasing anti-German feeling. This was the first report which had been received recently regarding Signor Mussilini's personal feelings.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Richmond Terrace S.W. 1
November 26, 1939
